case_text.case_text:
For Patricia A. George, as the Personal Representative of the Estate of Lawrence J. George, Plaintiff: Chris S. Dodig, Donovan & OConnor, LLP, North Adams, MA; Michael R. Hinkley, Donovan & O'Connor, North Adams, MA.For William Lowe, Jr., Defendant: Kevin P. Lohan, Logan & Lohan, LLP, Quincy, MA.For SEMAC Electric Co., Inc., Defendant: Scott M. Carroll, LEAD ATTORNEY, Boyle, Shaughnessy & Campo, P.C., Boston, MA; Patrick Driscoll, Boyle, Shaughnessy & Campo, P.C., Boston, MA.KATHERINE A. ROBERTSON, United States Magistrate Judge.KATHERINE A. ROBERTSONMEMORANDUM AND ORDER WITH REGARD TO DEFENDANT SEMAC ELECTRIC CO., INC.'s MOTION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT

(Dkt. No. 35)

ROBERTSON, U.S.M.J.

On May 15, 2014, Patricia George ("Plaintiff") filed this action against William D. Lowe, Jr. ("Lowe") and Semac Electric Co., Inc. ("Semac") (together "Defendants"). The complaint arises out of a fatal automobile collision that occurred on the morning of November 24, 2013 on Route 7 in Williamstown, Massachusetts. Currently before the court is Semac's motion for summary judgment on Counts III and IV of Plaintiff's wrongful death action (Dkt. No. 35), which Plaintiff has opposed (Dkt. No. 37). Jurisdiction is based on diversity of citizenship. See U.S.C. § 1332(a)(1). The parties have consented to this court's jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 636(c) and Fed. R. Civ. P. 73 (Dkt. No. 30). For the reasons stated below, Semac's motion for summary judgment is granted.

I. Standard of Review

On a motion for summary judgment, the court must determine whether "the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law." Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c). A fact is material if it would affect the outcome of the case under the controlling law. See United States v. One Parcel of Real Prop. (New Shoreham, R.I.), 960 F.2d 200, 204 (1st Cir.1992). A genuine issue exists as to such a fact if there is evidence from which a reasonable trier of fact could decide the fact either way. See id. The non-moving party bears the burden of placing at least one material fact into dispute after the moving party shows the absence of any disputed material fact. See Mendes v. Medtronic, Inc., 18 F.3d 13, 15 (1st Cir. 1994) (citing Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 324, 106 S. Ct. 2548, 91 L. Ed. 2d 265 (1986)). "In conducting this canvass of the record, we must take the evidence in the light most flattering to the party opposing summary judgment, indulging all reasonable inferences in that party's favor." Cochran v. Quest Software, Inc., 328 F.3d 1, 6 (1st Cir. 2003) (citing Griggs—Ryan v. Smith, 904 F.2d 112, 115 (1st Cir. 1990)).

II. Factual Background

The parties do not dispute the following facts, which are viewed in the light most favorable to Plaintiff, the non-moving party.

On or around September 4, 2013, Semac's Vice President, John Orzel, interviewed Lowe for a job as a journeyman electrician for a Semac construction project at Williams College (Dkt. No. 40, ¶¶ 8, 44). Following the interview, Lowe was offered and accepted employment with Semac, contingent on his passing a "fit-for-duty test" consisting of urinalysis and a basic physical exam (id., ¶¶ 9, 54). Lowe successfully completed the test and took part in new hire orientation on September 6, 2013 (id., ¶¶ 11, 56). Mr. Orzel believed that Mr. Lowe had a history of problems with alcohol, but Lowe reported being sober for a period of months at the time of hire (id., ¶¶ 48-49, 55). After Lowe's hiring, but prior to the November 24, 2013 accident, Semac received an anonymous message from "Amanda Love" ("Love") (id, ¶18). The message, which was a copy of an online conversation between Lowe and Love, included admissions by Lowe of his drug and alcohol usage (id., ¶¶ 18-20, 68-70). The record contains additional evidence of substance and alcohol abuse by Lowe and of a history of recent motor vehicle infractions (id., ¶¶ 63-65, 84-86).

The record is unclear about precisely when Lowe started work in Williamstown, but it does reflect that for several weeks prior to the accident, while Lowe worked at Williams College, Semac paid for Lowe to stay at a motel in Williamstown during the work week, from Sunday through Thursday nights (id., ¶¶ 7, 81). After leaving work on Friday at 10:45 a.m., rather than travelling home to Connecticut, Lowe reserved a motel room for himself and a female companion in Stockbridge, Massachusetts (id., ¶¶ 14, 106; Dkt. No. 38-3 at 4). He and his companion stayed at the motel in Stockbridge from Friday evening until approximately 10:00 a.m. on Sunday morning, November 24, 2013 (id, ¶ 90). On Sunday, at approximately 10:40 a.m., Lowe was driving his personal vehicle on Route 7 in Williamstown when he collided with a vehicle driven by Lawrence George (Dkt. No. 40, ¶¶ 1, 25). Mr. George was critically injured in the crash and succumbed to his injures (id., ¶ 2).

During the weekend in question, Lowe left the worksite on Friday, November 22, 2013, two days prior to the collision. He was not due back at the work site until Monday, November 25, 2013 (id., ¶ 13). On the day of the collision, Lowe was under no obligation from Semac to stay in Williamstown and he did not perform any work at Semac's direction that day (id, ¶¶ 12, 15). At the time of the collision, Lowe was traveling with his female companion from the motel in Stockbridge to the motel in Williamstown paid for by Semac (id., ¶ 97).

Lowe admitted to consuming alcohol, cocaine and marijuana on the night prior to the collision, followed by a beer at 9:00 a.m. on Sunday morning and another beer immediately prior to the accident (id., ¶¶ 23-24, 96, 98). On November 4, 2014, Lowe pled guilty to one count of negligent motor vehicle homicide (id., ¶ 103). All counts related to operating under the influence of a drug or narcotic were dropped (id., ¶ 27). Lowe was sentenced to time served and a 15 year revocation of his license (id., ¶ 103).

III. Discussion

Plaintiff's complaint alleges that both Defendants are liable for George's wrongful death and the associated damages caused by the collision (Dkt. No. 1). Counts I and II seek relief from Lowe (id., ¶¶ 11-19). In Count III of her complaint, Plaintiff alleges that Lowe was employed by Semac and acting within the scope of his employment at the time of the fatal collision. Accordingly, Plaintiff alleges that Semac is vicariously liable for Lowe's conduct under the doctrine of respondeat superior (id., ¶¶ 20-22). Count IV alleges that Semac negligently hired, retained, and supervised Lowe, who had a history of incidents involving substance abuse and motor vehicle infractions (id., ¶¶ 24-29). Semac has moved for summary judgment on Counts III and IV of the complaint (Dkt. No. 35). "In this case, the parties agree that Massachusetts law applies." Merlonghi v. U.S., 620 F.3d 50, 54 (1st Cir. 2010).

A. Plaintiff's claim of respondeat superior against Semac (Count III)1. The three-factor test

Under the doctrine of respondeat superior, "an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment." Id. at 54-55 (citing Lev v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, 457 Mass. 234, 929 N.E.2d 303, 308 (Mass. 2010)). Massachusetts courts determine whether an employee's conduct is within the scope of his employment "based on (1) 'whether the conduct in question is the kind the employee is hired to perform,' (2) 'whether it occurs within authorized time and space limits,' and (3) 'whether it is motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer.'" Id. at 55 (quoting Clickner v. City of Lowell, 422 Mass. 539, 663 N.E.2d 852, 855 (Mass. 1996)); see also Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 308 (applying three-factor test to determine scope of employment). Whether an employee was acting within the scope of employment when the employee committed allegedly wrongful conduct is a fact specific inquiry. See, e.g., Merlonghi, 620 F.3d at 57; Clickner, 663 N.E.2d at 855-56. Plaintiff has the burden of proving that Lowe was acting within the scope of his employment when he caused the accident. See Kelly v. Middlesex Corp., 35 Mass. App. Ct. 30, 616 N.E.2d 473, 474 (Mass. App. Ct. 1993) (citing Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc., 398 Mass. 854, 501 N.E.2d 1163, 1167 (Mass. 1986)).

Plaintiff contends that Lowe was acting within the scope of his employment because he was expected or required to use his personal vehicle to drive to and from a work site that was distant from his home; he used his vehicle to store and transport safety equipment — i.e., a hard hat — that Semac issued to him; he was working in Williamstown rather than in Connecticut, his primary residence; and Semac paid for lodging in Williamstown so that he would be close to the Williams College job site (Dkt. No. 37; Dkt. No. 40 at ¶¶ 7, 16, 67, 77, 106). In response, Semac points out that the collision took place during non-business hours — at 10:40 a.m. on a Sunday — and contends that Lowe was not serving any of Semac's business purposes when he caused Mr. George's death. Rather, he had decided to stay in Stockbridge for the weekend for personal reasons (Dkt. No. 40, ¶¶ 1-2, 12, 14-15, 17, 25).

In the court's view, under the three factor test established by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Semac has the better of these arguments. As to the first factor, it is undisputed that Lowe was hired by Semac to work as an electrician, not as a driver (id., ¶ 5). Cf. Merlonghi, 620 F.3d at 56 (although employee was in vehicle owned by federal government at time of accident, engaging in car chase was not type of conduct federal employee was hired to perform). At the time of the accident, Lowe was "driving his own vehicle[,]" Kelly, 616 N.E.2d at 476 (that employee was driving his own vehicle was factor in determination employee was not acting within scope of employment); contrast Clickner (that employee was driving car registered to city was fact tending to show he was acting within scope of employment), and he was not scheduled to report to work until 7:00 a.m. the next day (Dkt. No. 40, ¶¶ 13, 17). Almost every employee presumably carries some tools of a trade, a uniform, or some other item supplied by his or her employer and related to work while driving to or from work. That Lowe may have transported a hard hat provided by Semac in his personal vehicle is not sufficient to "'tip the balance to bring [his] conduct with the scope of employment.'" Merlonghi, 620 F.3d at 56 (quoting Clickner, 663 N.E.2d at 856). Second, the accident occurred on a Sunday morning while Lowe was engaged in a weekend excursion with a female companion (Dkt. No. 40, ¶¶ 1, 17). Lowe had last worked on Friday and was not due back on the job site until Monday morning (id, ¶ 13). Plaintiff admits that Lowe did not perform any work for Semac on the day of the accident and that Lowe was under no obligation to Semac to stay in Williamstown over the weekend (id., ¶¶ 12, 15). Accordingly, Lowe's negligent driving did not "occur[] within authorized time and space limits." Clickner, 663 N.E.2d at 855; see also Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 308.

Finally, the record cannot support a finding that Lowe's conduct on Sunday was motivated at least in part by a purpose to serve his employer. See Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 308. It is undisputed that Lowe's weekend stay in Stockbridge with a female companion was a personal choice and that Semac did not control any of his activities on the weekend. Semac paid for Lowe's lodgings Sunday through Thursday night to ensure he could arrive at the job site in a timely fashion. Semac did not provide weekend lodging and Lowe did not even stay in Williamstown over the weekend. See, e.g., Merlonghi, 620 F.3d at 57 (conduct related to personal travel and personal confrontation not motivated by purpose to serve employer); Clickner, 663 N.E.2d at 856 (employee not acting within scope of employment where his "actions throughout the day of the accident were in the furtherance of his own agenda").

Plaintiff places great weight on the fact that, when Lowe caused the accident, he was driving to lodgings in Williamstown that were being paid for by Semac (Dkt. No. 37 at 3-4). "In addition to the three factor test, the [Supreme Judicial Court] has a long-established 'going and coming' rule: 'Generally speaking, travel to and from home to a place of employment is not considered to be within the scope of employment.'" Merlonghi, 620 F.3d at 55 (quoting Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 308). In Lev, the Supreme Judicial Court ("SJC") held than an employee who attended a work meeting at a bar, where he became intoxicated, was no longer acting within the scope of his employment when he left the bar to drive home, causing an accident while he was en route. Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 308-09. The SJC stated that this conduct, "substantively, was no different than traveling home after completion of his shift" and "was not an essential part of his employer's mission." Id. at 309. Similarly, in Clickner, the SJC held than a police officer who was on-call, driving a car owned by the city to his place of work, and responding to a page at the time of the accident, was not acting within the scope of his employment. Clickner, 663 N.E.2d at 855-56. Like Lowe, the employee in Clickner had spent the day engaged in personal activities, which included consuming alcohol. He was driving to work from a golfing function. Id. at 856. The court held that the employee "was not acting in furtherance of his employer's business simply because he was going to work." Id. at 855.

In view of the facts in Lev and Clickner, Plaintiff's half-hearted assertion that the going and coming rule applies only when an employee is travelling directly between home and work is unpersuasive (Dkt. No. 37 at 4).

 Based on the undisputed facts in this case, the going and coming rule, as applied in Lev, Clickner, and cases cited therein, dictates the conclusion that Lowe — who, at most, was going to a location associated with his work — was not acting within the scope of his employment when he caused the accident that killed Mr. George.

2. Special Mission

Acknowledging that there are no Massachusetts cases on point, Plaintiff points to cases in other jurisdictions recognizing a "special mission" or "special errand" exception to the going and coming rule.

In Allen v. Bd. of Selectmen of Weymouth, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1009, 448 N.E.2d 782 (Mass. App. Ct. 1983) (rescript), the court referred to a police officer's mandated trip to court to testify on his day off as a "special mission" and held that the officer's direct drive home from the court house, during which he was injured in an accident, was part of his employment. Id. at 783. In Domingo v. Town of Wellesley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 793, 694 N.E.2d 43 (Mass. App. Ct. 1998), the court explained that the result in Allen was because "the officer was ordered by his superiors to travel on his day off[.]" Id. at 797 (emphasis in original). Allen and Domingo are workers compensation cases involving public employees. These cases are distinguishable on their facts from the case at bar and provide relatively little guidance in resolving the issues presently before this court.

"This 'special mission' exception arises when the employer calls the employee away from his regular place of work for the purposes of the employer and to benefit the employer." Fitzpatrick v. U.S., 754 F. Supp. 1023, 1035 (D. Del. 1991); see alsoLexington Ins. Co. v. Henkels & McCoy, Inc., No. Civ.A. 02-0764, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11970, 2002 WL 32130104 (E.D. Pa. May 20, 2003); Jeewarat v. Warner Bros. Entm't, 177 Cal. App. 4th 427, 98 Cal. Rptr. 3d 837 (Cal. Ct. App. 2009) (employer potentially liable for employee's collision that occurred on the way home from a business trip which the court deemed a "special errand/mission"); Makoske v. Lombardy, 47 A.D.2d 284, 366 N.Y.S.2d 475 (N.Y. App. Div. 1975) (employer found liable for collision that occurred while employees who were staying out of town on employer's business were sight-seeing). In Lexington, an employee from Oregon was on an extended business trip in Pennsylvania, which the employer subsidized at the rate of $40.00 a day, when the employee negligently left an oil-filled pan unattended on a stove in his hotel room, resulting in a fire that caused damage to the hotel property. See Lexington, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11970, 2002 WL 32130104, at *2. In denying the employer's motion for summary judgment, the court, applying Pennsylvania law, held that a reasonable juror could conclude that the employee's conduct in his hotel room during a non-work day was within the scope of his employment. 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11970, [WL] at *4.

Under Pennsylvania law, "it is not necessary . . . that the acts be specifically authorized by the master to fall within the scope of employment; it is sufficient if they are clearly incidental to the master's business." Lexington, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11970, 2002 WL 32130104, at *2 (quoting Shuman Estate v. Weber, 276 Pa. Super. 209, 419 A.2d 169, 173 (Pa. Super.1980) (citing Restatement (Second) Agency § 228 (1957)).

 The "special mission" rule shifts "the normal risks inherent in the employee's travels" onto the employer. Fitzpatrick, 754 F. Supp. at 1035 (citing Short v. U.S., 245 F. Supp. 591, 593 (D. Del. 1965)). A "special mission" can be part of regular duties or a "specific order or request" of an employer, and "the employee is considered to be in the scope of his employment from the time that he starts on the errand until he has returned or until he deviates therefrom for personal reasons." Id. (quoting Short, 245 F. Supp. at 593); see also, e.g., Jeewarat, 98 Cal. Rptr. 3d at 844-45.

Assuming for the sake of argument that the Massachusetts courts would, in an appropriate case, adopt some form of a "special mission" exception to the going and coming rule, it would not apply here. In the cases on which Plaintiff relies, the employer required the allegedly negligent employee to be in the location where the accident occurred, or the employee was in that location in furtherance of the employer's interests. Plaintiff lived in Connecticut and worked for Semac in Massachusetts. The location of his employment with Semac was not so remote from his home that it was impractical for him to return home for the weekend. Contrast Lexington, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11970, 2002 WL 32130104, at *2 (employees who were working in Pennsylvania technically were permitted to return home to Oregon for weekend, but such travel would not have been reimbursed). Semac had no interest in, or control over, Lowe's activities on the weekend and only paid for Lowe's lodgings from Sunday to Thursday nights. Contrast Lexington, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11970, 2002 WL 32130104, at *2 (employer paid weekend per diem and for weekend lodgings); Jeewarat, 98 Cal. Rptr. 3d at 845 (employee on special mission is within scope of employment during "entire trip from his home to work and back to his home"); Makoske, 47 A.D.2d at 287-88 (employer liable for injuries caused by accident where it had "marooned" its employees for four days in location of business conference). It is undisputed that Lowe spent the weekend in Stockbridge for reasons wholly unrelated to Semac's interests. Contrast Fitzpatrick, 754 F. Supp. at 1035 (Sergeant in Delaware for weekend because he was required to train Army Reserves and National Guard was on special mission for entire weekend; Army was liable for accident he caused). In the court's view, Plaintiff's respondeat superior claim is barred by the going and coming rule as that rule has been applied by the Massachusetts courts in Lev and Clickner. In Lev, the Court held that as soon as the employee left the location where he was meeting with his supervisor, his activities were outside of the scope of his employment. Lowe left the Semac work site and the motel in Williamstown that Semac paid for on Friday. His activities after he left the Semac work site on Friday at 10:45 a.m. were outside of the scope of his employment. On Sunday, he was driving to a location associated with work when he caused the accident. Under Massachusetts law, an employee is not acting in furtherance of an employer's business simply because he or she is driving to a location associated with work. See Clickner, 663 N.E.2d at 855-56; see also Merlonghi, 620 F.3d at 58. Indeed, Plaintiff has identified no case, let alone legal authority in Massachusetts, applying the special mission exception to facts analogous to the facts in this case.

Because Semac has met its burden of demonstrating that there is no genuine issue of material fact as to Plaintiff's claim of liability based on respondeat superior, Semac is entitled to judgment as a matter of law on Count III.

B. Plaintiff's claim of negligent hiring, retention, and/or supervision (Count IV)

In order to prevail on a claim of negligence, "'a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.'" Lev, 929 N.E.2d. at 309 (quoting Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d 829, 834-35 (Mass. 2006)). Where a defendant does not owe a plaintiff a duty of care, there can be no actionable negligence. The existence of a duty of care is a question of law, making it appropriate for summary judgement. Id., 929 N.E.2d. at 309 (citing Jupin, 849 N.E.2d at 835). Plaintiff contends that a duty of care exists based on the "special relationship" that exists between an employer and an employee, and because, she asserts, Semac had a common law duty to protect prospective plaintiffs from someone like Lowe, who had a history of substance and alcohol abuse and a poor driving record. Semac asserts that the claims for negligent hiring and retention fail as a matter of law because Semac did not owe Mr. George a duty of care (Dkt. No. 35 at 2).

1. "Special relationship" between employer and employee

Generally, all persons have a personal duty to "exercise reasonable care in their own conduct to avoid harming others where the risk of harm is foreseeable to the actor." Roe No. 1 v. Children's Hosp. Med. Ctr., 469 Mass. 710, 16 N.E.3d 1044, 1048 (Mass. 2014) (citations omitted). That duty does not normally extend to controlling the conduct of third parties unless a "'special relationship' exists between the party posing a risk to others and the party who can prevent that harm from occurring by taking action." Roe No. 1, 16 N.E.3d at 1048 (citing Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 311). The relationship between employers and employees has been recognized as a type of "special relationship" that "potentially would give rise to a duty of care [to third parties] . . . when 'the employment facilitates the employee's causing harm.'" Id. "Employment facilitates harm to others when the employment provides the employee access to physical locations, such as the place of employment, or to instrumentalities, such as a police officer carrying a concealed weapon while off duty, or other means by which to cause harm that would otherwise not be available to the employee." Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 312 (citing Restatement (Third) of Torts: Liability for Physical Harm§ 41 cmt. at e. (Proposed Final Draft No. 1, 2005)). In those circumstances where a special relationship does exist, an employer is "responsible for exercising reasonable care to ensure that [its] employees do not cause foreseeable harm to a foreseeable class of plaintiffs." Roe No. 1, 16 N.E.3d at 1048 (citing Coughlin, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633, 767 N.E.2d 106) (under a theory of negligent employment a foreseeable class would consist of employees and business invitees).

Plaintiff bears the burden of proving that Semac owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care. See, e.g., Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 309. Based on the undisputed facts in this case, she cannot establish such a duty on Semac's part predicated on the special relationship between an employer and an employee. Mr. George was driving on Route 7 at the time of the collision, and was neither an employee nor a business invitee of Semac. See Coughlin, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633, 767 N.E.2d 106; contrast Foster v. Loft, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289, 526 N.E.2d 1309, 1310 (Mass. App. Ct. 1988) (employer violated duty of care by retaining as employee bartender with criminal record of violence where bartender was in contact with members of public in course of employer's business). Nor did Semac provide Lowe with any instrumentality that caused injury to Mr. George. Semac did not provide Lowe with access to Williamstown or to Route 7, the public highway on which the collision occurred, nor did the vehicle Lowe was driving at the time of the accident belong to Semac. See Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 312.

To the extent Plaintiff's claim is premised on the possibility that Lowe was intoxicated when he caused the accident, it is well-established under Massachusetts law that an employer is liable for an accident attributable to an employee's intoxication only when the employer controls the alcohol that is provided to the impaired employee. Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 310-11. The facts in this case do not support an inference that Semac controlled the alcohol consumed by Lowe before he caused the accident. As a matter of law, then, "[Lowe's] employment with [Semac] did not facilitate his ability to harm the plaintiff. Therefore, there was no special relationship between [Semac] and [Lowe] that gave rise to a duty of care for the benefit of the plaintiff." Id. at 312.

2. Common law duty between defendant and prospective plaintiffs

Massachusetts courts "also have recognized, on occasion, a 'special relationship' between a defendant and prospective plaintiffs." Roe No. 1, 16 N.E.3d at 1050. See generally, e.g., McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 398 Mass. 152, 496 N.E.2d 141 (Mass. 1986) (social host has duty to potential class of victims to stop serving individual he reasonably should know is intoxicated); Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 233 N.E.2d 18 (Mass. 1968) (owner of tavern has duty to potential class of victims not to serve intoxicated patron); Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (Mass. 1983) (college owed duty of care to students where colleges generally had taken steps to provide an adequate level of security on campus). Such a relationship generally is recognized only where "the defendant could reasonably anticipate that his or her failure to take prompt action in circumstances that he or she controlled could result in harm to a clearly defined class of plaintiffs." Roe No. 1, 16 N.E.3d at 1050. "There must be limits to the scope or definition of reasonable foreseeability based on considerations of policy and pragmatic judgment." Coughlin, 767 N.E.2d at 112 (citing Griffiths v. Campbell, 425 Mass. 31, 679 N.E.2d 536, 540 (Mass. 1997)).

Any contention by plaintiff that the law would recognize such a special relationship between Semac and Mr. George is unavailing. First, there is no evidence to suggest that Semac controlled Lowe's conduct during the weekend, or that it controlled the surrounding circumstances when Lowe drove down Route 7 in Williamstown on Sunday morning. Lowe was not on-call on the day of the accident, did not perform any work that day at Semac's direction, and had no intention of returning to work until Monday, November 25, 2013 (Dkt. No. 40 at ¶¶ 12-13). He was driving his personal vehicle on Route 7, a public highway, at the time of the accident. Lowe had no ability to supervise or monitor Lowe's weekend conduct. See Roe No. 1, 16 N.E.3d at 1049 (former employer of doctor accused of sexual abuse of children had no duty of care to potential plaintiffs where employer no longer had ability to supervise or monitor former employee). Second, there is no evidence to show that Semac had the ability to take "prompt action" to intervene and prevent harm arising from Lowe's activities on his day off. There is no evidence that Semac knew about Lowe's weekend activities or could have prevented him from driving his personal vehicle. Contrast Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 467 N.E.2d 1292, 1299-1304 (Mass. 1984) (town liable to injured motorist where police officer failed to remove intoxicated driver from highways). Where Plaintiff has not established that Semac owed any duty of care to Mr. George, plaintiff's claim of negligence fails as a matter of law. See Roe No. 1, 16 N.E.3d at 1048 (citing Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 801 N.E.2d 260, 262 (Mass. 2004)).

Finally, Plaintiff claims that a duty of care may be premised on Semac's alleged failure to comply with its own employment policies. She points to Semac's failures to check Lowe's employment history, abide by its tardiness policy, and conduct employee drug tests (Dkt. No. 37 at 14-15; Dkt. No. 40 at ¶¶ 87-93). While such failures may provide evidence of a breach, they do not establish a duty where one "does not exist independently." Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 313 (quoting Goulart v. Canton Hous. Auth., 57 Mass. App. Ct. 440, 783 N.E.2d 864, 868 (Mass. App. Ct. 2003) (violation of written snow removal policy does not provide independent basis for liability)). Additionally, where, as here, such policies are not "designed for the protection of the public at large . . . [those policies] may not serve as the basis for the plaintiff's negligence claim." Id. at 314 (citations omitted).

To conclude that Semac owed a duty of care to Mr. George would be to support "[i]mposing a potentially onerous burden on employers to monitor the off-premises conduct of all of their employees to ensure that no harm comes to third parties," and that "is a duty that [the Massachusetts courts] have not previously recognized, and [that this court cannot] recognize now." Lev, 929 N.E.2d at 314; see also Quality Cleaning Prods. R.C., Inc. v. SCA Tissue N. Am., LLC, 794 F.3d 200, 207 (1st Cir. 2015) ("A federal court sitting in diversity cannot be expected to create new doctrines expanding state law.") (quotation omitted). Semac has met its burden of demonstrating that there is no genuine issue of material fact, and that it is entitled to judgment as a matter of law on Count IV.

IV. Conclusion

For the foregoing reasons, Defendant Semac's Motion for Summary Judgment is GRANTED.

IT IS SO ORDERED.

/s/ Katherine A. Robertson

KATHERINE A. ROBERTSON

United States Magistrate Judge

DATED: January11, 2016

case_text.case_text:
For Ricardo Montanez-Quinones, Defendant: Melanie Carrillo-Jimenez, LEAD ATTORNEY, Lcda. Melanie Carrillo-Jimenez, San Juan, PR.For USA, Plaintiff: Ginette L. Milanes, LEAD ATTORNEY, U.S. Attorney's Office, District of Puerto Rico, San Juan, PR.CAMILLE L. VELEZ-RIVE, UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE.CAMILLE L. VELEZ-RIVEREPORT AND RECOMMENDATION

Defendant Ricardo Montañez-Quiñones was charged in Counts One through Three of an Indictment and he agreed to plead guilty to Count Three of the Indictment. Count Three charges that on or about December 18, 2015, in the District of Puerto Rico, and elsewhere within the jurisdiction of this Court, the defendant herein, did knowingly possess one or more matters, which contained any visual depiction that had been shipped or transported in or affecting interstate and foreign commerce and had been produced using materials which have been mailed, shipped and transported in or affecting interstate and foreign commerce, and the production of which involved the use of a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct, and the visual depiction was of such conduct; that is, on or about December 18, 2015, RICARDO MONTAÑEZ-QUIÑONES, did knowingly possess on his Sony VAIO laptop computer with a Western Digital hard drive manufactured in Korea, serial number K41LT852EDIG, with access to the internet, and his Compaq desktop computer with a Western Digital hard drive manufactured in Thailand, serial number WCAM98373596, with access to the internet, one or more image files depicting minors, including prepubescent minors, engaging in sexually explicit conduct, as defined in Title 18, United States Code, Section 2256(2), such as, visual depictions of the lascivious exhibition of the genital areas. All in violation of Title 18, United States Code, Sections 2252A(a)(5)(B) and (b)(2).

On September 8, 2016, defendant appeared before this Magistrate Judge, since the Rule11 hearing was referred by the Court. Defendant was provided with a Waiver of Right to Trial by Jury, which he signed and agreed upon voluntarily after examination in open court, under oath.

Defendant indicated and confirmed his intention to plead guilty to Count Three of the Indictment, upon being advised of his right to have said proceedings before a district judge of this court.

The form entitled Consent to Proceed before a United States Magistrate Judge in a Felony Case for Pleading Guilty (Rule 11, Fed.R.Crim.P.) and Waiver of Jury Trial, signed and consented by both parties is made part of the record.

 Upon verifying through defendant's statement his age, education and any relevant aspect as to the use of medication, drugs, alcohol or substance dependency, and psychological or psychiatric condition, to ascertain his capacity and ability to understand, answer and comprehend the interactive colloquy with this Magistrate Judge, a determination was made as to defendant's competency and ability to understand the proceedings.

Having further advised defendant of the charges contained in above-stated Count Three, he was examined and verified as being correct that: he had consulted with his counsel Melanie Carrillo-Jiménez, prior to the hearing for change of plea, that he was satisfied with the services provided by his legal representative and had time to discuss with her all aspects of the case, insofar, among other things, regarding the change of plea, the consent to proceed before a United States Magistrate Judge, the content of the Indictment and the charges therein, his constitutional rights and the consequences of the waiver of same.

Defendant was specifically apprised by this Magistrate Judge that, upon withdrawing his initial plea of not guilty and now entering a plea of guilty to the charge specified, he was waiving his right to a public, speedy, and a trial by jury constituted by twelve jurors who have to unanimously agree to a verdict. He was also waiving his right to be presumed innocent and for the government to meet the obligation of establishing his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Furthermore, he was waiving his right during said trial to confront the witnesses who were to testify against him and be able to cross-examine them, through counsel at said trial, as well as present evidence on his behalf. He was also waiving the right to compel the attendance of witnesses and that subpoenas be issued to have them appear in court to testify. Defendant was specifically apprised of his right to take the stand and testify, if he so decided, or not to testify, and no inference or decision as to his guilt could be made from the fact if he decides not to testify. Defendant was also explained his right not to incriminate himself; that upon such a waiver of all above-discussed rights a judgment of guilty and his sentence were to be based on his plea of guilty, and he would be sentenced by the judge after considering the information contained in a pre-sentence report.

As to all the above, defendant provided an individualized and positive acknowledgment of each and every waiver and, with the assistance of his counsel indicated he freely and voluntarily waived those rights and understood the consequences. During all this colloquy, defendant was made aware that he could freely request from this Magistrate Judge any additional clarification, repetition, or ask questions and that he may consult with his attorney at any given time as to any issue.

Defendant expressed his understanding of the penalties prescribed by statute for the offenses as to which he was pleading guilty. The maximum penalty for the offense charged in Count Three of the Indictment (Possession of Child Pornography) is twenty (20) years of incarceration, see, Title 18, United States Code, Sections 2252A(a)(5)(B) and (b)(2), a fine of not more than two-hundred and fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00), see, Title 18, United States Code, Section 3571(b)(3), and a term of supervised release of not LESS than five (5) years up to life, in addition to any term of imprisonment. See, Title 18, United States Code, §§ 3559(a)(3) (Class "C" Felony) and 3583(k).

At the time of sentencing, the defendant will pay a special monetary assessment of one hundred dollars ($100.00), as required by Title 18, United States Code, Section 3013(a).

Having ascertained directly from defendant that he had not been induced in any way to plead guilty, that no one had forced him in any way to plead guilty, nor that he had been offered any reward or any other thing of value to get him to plead guilty, the document entitled "Plea Agreement in accordance with Rule 11(c)(1)(A) & (B))" ("the Agreement") and the "Plea Agreement Supplement"

Defendant acknowledged discussing the "Plea Agreement Supplement" with his counsel and stated he understood the terms and consequences of the same. Defense counsel recognized she explained to defendant the content of the "Plea Agreement Supplement" and explained to defendant its consequences.

were shown to defendant, verifying his signature and initials on each and every page.

Pursuant to said Agreement, and insofar as Count Three, as to which defendant already was aware of the maximum possible penalties, defendant was apprised that it was up to the sole discretion of the sentencing court what the sentence to be imposed on him will be. Defendant was specifically informed that if the sentencing court were to impose a sentence which turned out to be higher or more severe than the one he might be expecting, for said reason alone, defendant would have no grounds for the court to allow him to withdraw his plea of guilty.

As to Count Three, the above-captioned parties' estimate and agreement that appears on page four (4), paragraph seven (7) of the Agreement, regarding the possible applicable advisory Sentencing Guidelines, were further elaborated and explained. Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 2G2.2(a)(1), the Base Offense Level is of Eighteen (18). Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 2G2.2(b)(2), an increase of two (2) levels is agreed for offense involved prepubescent minors. Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 2G2.2(b)(3)(F), an increase of two (2) levels is agreed for offense involved distribution. Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 2G2.2(b)(4), an increase of four (4) levels is agreed for offense involved material that portrays sadistic or masochistic conduct. Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 2G2.2(b)(6), an increase of two (2) levels is agreed for offense involved use of a computer. Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 2G2.2(b)(7)(B), an increase of three (3) levels is agreed because, for the purposes of this Plea Agreement, the parties stipulate that the offense involved more than 150 but fewer than 300 images. Pursuant to U.S.S.G. § 3E1.1(b), a decrease of three (3) levels is agreed for acceptance of responsibility. Therefore, the Total Offense Level is of Twenty-Eight (28), yielding an imprisonment range of 78 to 97 months assuming a Criminal History Category of I; 87 to 108 months assuming a Criminal History Category of II; and 97 to 121 months assuming a Criminal History Category of III.

There is no stipulation as to defendant's Criminal History Category.

The defendant agrees to forfeit all the digital material that either tested positive for the presence of child pornography or was in any way used to transport or possess child pornography, including but not limited to one Sony VAIO laptop computer with a Western Digital hard drive which was manufactured in Korea, with serial number K41LT852EDIG and one Compaq desktop computer with a Western Digital hard drive which was manufactured in Thailand, bearing serial number WCAM98373596.

In exchange for the defendant pleading guilty to Count Three of the Indictment, the parties agree to allow the defendant to argue for a sentence at the lower end of the applicable Sentencing Guidelines range based on a total offense level of 28 and the United States reserve the right to argue for a sentence up to the middle of the applicable Sentencing Guidelines range based on a total offense level of 28. Assuming at the time of sentencing the defendant's Criminal History Category is one (1), the parties agree that the middle of the applicable Sentencing Guidelines range is eighty-seven (87) months. The defendant agrees that this sentence is reasonable pursuant to Title 18, United States Code, § 3553(a).

The United States agrees to dismiss Counts One and Two (Transportation of Child Pornography) in violation of 18 U.S.C. § 2252A(a)(1).

The United States and defendant agree that no further adjustments or departures to defendant's total adjusted base offense level shall be sought. The parties agree that any request by defendant for an adjustment or departure will be considered a material breach of this Plea Agreement, and the United States will be free to ask for any sentence, either guideline or statutory.

As part of the written Agreement, the government, the defendant, and his counsel also agreed they are aware that the Sentencing Guidelines are no longer mandatory and are thus considered advisory.

Defendant acknowledges that by pleading guilty and entering into this plea agreement, he will be required to register as a "Sex Offender" pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act ("SORNA" or "the Act"), which was enacted under title I of the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 (P.L. 109-248), codified at Title 18, United States Code, Section 2250 and title 42, United States Code, Section 16913. As a registered Sex Offender, defendant further understands that his status as a convicted sex offender, and related Indictment, will be made public. Defendant further acknowledges that he may or may not be required to register for life.

The government presented to this Magistrate Judge and to defendant, assisted by his counsel, a summary of the basis in fact for the offenses charged and the evidence the government had available to establish, in the event defendant had elected to go to trial, the commission of the offense, beyond a reasonable doubt. Counsel and defendant acknowledged the evidence of the government was fully disclosed to them and previously discussed between the two. Defendant was also read and shown a document entitled "Government's Version of Facts", which had been signed by defendant and his counsel and is attached to the Agreement, wherein the signature of counsel for the government also appears. Defendant was able to understand the explanation and agreed with the government's submission.

Defendant was explained that the Agreement with the government does not bind any other district, except the district of Puerto Rico, and it contained all the promises, terms and conditions which defendant, his attorney and the government, have entered.

Having once more ascertained that defendant has indicated not being induced to plead guilty, and was entering such a plea because in fact he is guilty, without any promises or predictions being made as to the sentence to be imposed by the court, defendant was informed that parole has been abolished under the advisory Sentencing Reform Act and that any sentence of imprisonment would be served, without him being released on parole. Defendant was additionally informed that prior to sentence, the sentencing judge will have a pre-sentence report and that it would be made available to him, to his counsel and to the government, so that they be allowed to correct or object to any information contained in said report which was not accurate.

Defendant was informed that he can appeal his conviction if he believes that his guilty plea was somehow unlawful or involuntary or if there is some other fundamental defect in the proceedings which was not waived by his guilty plea. Defendant was also informed that he has a statutory right to appeal his sentence under certain circumstances particularly if the sentence is contrary to law. With few exceptions, any notice of appeal must be filed within fourteen (14) days of judgment being entered in the case. Defendant was also apprised the right to appeal is subject to certain limitations allowed by law because his Plea Agreement contains a waiver of appeal in paragraph eighteen (18) which was read to defendant in open court. Defendant recognized having knowledge of the waiver of appeal, discussing the same with his counsel and understanding its consequences. Defense counsel acknowledged discussing the waiver of appeal and its consequences with his client.

Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment in open court because he is aware of its content, indicating he availed himself of the opportunity to further discuss same with his attorney and then he positively stated that what was contained in Count Three was what he had done and to which he was pleading guilty during these proceedings. Thereafter, defendant expressed in no uncertain terms that he agreed with the government's evidence as to his participation in the offense. Thereupon, defendant indicated he was pleading guilty to Count Three of the Indictment in Criminal No. 16-150 (CCC).

This Magistrate Judge after having explained to the defendant his rights, ascertaining that he was acting freely and voluntarily to the waiver of such rights and in his decision of pleading guilty, with full knowledge of the consequences thereof, and there being a basis in fact for such a plea, is recommending that a plea of guilty be entered as to Count Three of the Indictment in Criminal No. 16-150 (CCC).

IT IS SO RECOMMENDED.

The sentencing hearing will be held on December 8, 2016 at 4:30 pm before Hon. Carmen C. Cerezo, District Judge.

The parties have fourteen (14) days to file any objections to this report and recommendation. Amended Fed. R. Crim P. 59 (b)(2). See also Amended Local Rules. Failure to file same within the specified time waives the right to appeal this order. Henley Drilling Co. v. McGee, 36 F.3d 143, 150-151 (1st Cir. 1994); United States v. Valencia, 792 F.2d 4 (1st Cir. 1986). See Paterson-Leitch Co. v. Mass. Mun. Wholesale Elec. Co., 840 F.2d 985, 991 (1st Cir. 1988).

San Juan, Puerto Rico, this 9th day of September of 2016.

/s/ CAMILLE L. VELEZ-RIVE

CAMILLE L. VELEZ-RIVE

UNITED STATES MAGISTRATE JUDGE

For E8 Pharmaceuticals LLC, Plaintiff: Gregory R. Lyons, James H. Wallace, Jr., John B. Wyss, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Wiley Rein LLp, Washington, DC; Kevin P. Anderson, LEAD ATTORNEY, Mark A. Pacella, Wiley Rein LLP, Washington, DC; Michael R. Gottfried, LEAD ATTORNEY, Christopher S. Kroon, Duane Morris LLP, Boston, MA.For Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Plaintiff: Gregory R. Lyons, ames H. Wallace, Jr., John B. Wyss, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Wiley Rein LLp, Washington, DC; James J. Foster, LEAD ATTORNEY, Hayes Messina Gilman & Hayes LLC, Boston, MA; Kevin P. Anderson, LEAD ATTORNEY, Mark A. Pacella, Wiley Rein LLP, Washington, DC; Michael A. Albert, LEAD ATTORNEY, Wolf, Greenfield & Sacks, PC, Boston, MA; Michael R. Gottfried, LEAD ATTORNEY, Christopher S. Kroon, Duane Morris LLP, Boston, MA.For Navigenics, Inc., Consolidated Defendant: Dale C. Kerester, John P. Dennis, Lynch, Brewer, Hoffman & Fink LLP, Boston, MA; Mark D. Shtilerman, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, New York, NY; Peter Fratangelo, Kaye Scholer LLP (NY), New York, NY; Peter E. Root, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, Palo Alto, CA; Robert M. Shaw, Holland & Knight (B), Boston, MA.For Affymetrix, Inc., Defendant: Barbara A. Caulfield, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, Menlo Park, CA; Michael J. Malecek, Peter E. Root, Stephen C. Holmes, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, Palo Alto, CA; Dale C. Kerester, John P. Dennis, Lynch, Brewer, Hoffman & Fink LLP, Boston, MA; Jeffrey S. Strom, Nystrom Beckman & Paris LLP, Boston, MA Mark D. Shtilerman, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, New York, NY; Peter Fratangelo, Kaye Scholer LLP (NY), New York, NY; Robert M. Shaw, Holland & Knight (B), Boston, MA.For Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Counter Defendant: Michael R. Gottfried, Duane Morris LLP, Boston, MA.For Affymetrix, Inc., Counter Claimant, Cross Claimant: Barbara A. Caulfield, LEAD ATTORNEY, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, Menlo Park, CA; Michael J. Malecek, Peter E. Root, Stephen C. Holmes, LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, Palo Alto, CA; Jeffrey S. Strom, Nystrom Beckman & Paris LLP, Boston, MA Mark D. Shtilerman, PRO HAC VICE, Kaye Scholer LLP, New York, NY; Peter Fratangelo, Kaye Scholer LLP (NY), New York, NY; Robert M. Shaw, Holland & Knight (B), Boston, MA.For E8 Pharmaceuticals LLC, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Counter Defendants:Gregory R. Lyons, ames H. Wallace, Jr., LEAD ATTORNEYS, PRO HAC VICE, Wiley Rein LLp, Washington, DC; John B. Wyss, LEAD ATTORNEY, Wiley Rein LLp, Washington, DC; Kevin P. Anderson, LEAD ATTORNEY, Mark A. Pacella, Wiley Rein LLP, Washington, DC; Michael R. Gottfried, LEAD ATTORNEY, Christopher S. Kroon, Duane Morris LLP, Boston, MA.George A. O'Toole, Jr., United States District Judge.George A. O'Toole, Jr.ORDER ON BILL OF COSTS

O'TOOLE, D.J.

I. Introduction

Defendant Affymetrix, Inc. has filed a bill of costs pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(d)(1). The plaintiffs, E8 Pharmaceuticals, LLC and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, object.

The award of costs is governed by 28 U.S.C. § 1920, which provides that the following may be taxed as costs: (1) fees of the clerk and marshal; (2) fees for transcripts necessarily obtained for use in the case; (3) fees and disbursements for printing and witnesses; (4) fees for exemplification and copies necessarily obtained for use in the case; (5) docket fees; and (6) compensation of court appointed experts and interpreters, and salaries, fees, expenses, and costs of special interpretation services. "The decision of a court to award costs must be carefully tailored to the statute devoted to the taxation of costs." (citing 28 U.S.C. § 1920). Although the Court has considerable discretion in awarding costs, such "discretion is limited to awarding costs that are within the scope of 28 U.S.C. § 1920." .

II. Discussion

Affymetrix seeks taxation of the following costs:

Deposition Costs: $65,727.12 (Ex. A)

Costs of Exemplification and Reproduction of Materials: $130,108.68

Documents Requested by Plaintiffs: $7,375.53 (Ex. B)

Internal Copies of Documents/Exhibits/Pleadings: $16,564.40 (Ex. C)

Visual Aids for Markman Hearing: $106,168.75 (Ex. D)

Total: $195,835.80

A. Depositions

A party seeking taxation of costs under Section 1920(2) must include supporting documentation to enable the court to assess whether the expenses were "necessarily obtained for use in the case." . In its Bill of Costs, Affymetrix included supporting documentation for only 9 of the 23 depositions for which costs are sought. Although it later provided the underlying invoices for the remaining 14 depositions, representing to the Court that it "inadvertently did not include the invoices," this gesture is too little, too late. Because of Affymetrix's oversight, the plaintiffs were compelled to engage in another round of briefing to respond to the late disclosed documentation.The Court declines to consider these invoices filed thirty-eight days after the filing of the Bill of Costs. The costs associated with these 14 depositions — totaling $15,475.42 — are disallowed.

In addition to fees for deposition transcripts, Affymetrix seeks costs for extra services like expedited transcripts, realtime transmission, ASCII transcripts, and video services, among others. Such extra costs are not within the narrow scope of Section 1920(2) under prevailing authority. See, e.g., ; see also Taxation of Costs (2000) at 3, http://www.mad.uscourts.gov/resources/pdf/taxation.pdf ("Taxation of Costs"). Only the costs of the transcripts, courier charges, and attendance fees will be allowed, totaling $14,981.85.

B. Documents Requested by Plaintiffs

The plaintiffs do not challenge the cost of exemplification and reproduction of materials requested by the plaintiffs, as documented in the SF Legal invoices (Bill of Costs, Ex. B (dkt. no. 238-3)) and totaling $7,375.53. These costs will be awarded.

C. Internal Copies

Affymetrix has provided a list of 326 sets of copies made by its law firm in connection with this litigation. Each entry includes the date, number of pages, the person making the copies, and the total charge. The plaintiffs challenge these costs, arguing that they do not provide enough detail for the Court to evaluate which copies were "necessarily obtained for use in the case" as required by Section 1920(4). The plaintiffs also contend that some of these copies appear to be duplicative of the costs covered by the SF Legal invoices.

The Federal Circuit in Summit Technology addressed this issue and acknowledged that "in complex patent litigation involving hundreds of thousands of documents and copies, parties cannot be expected to track the identity of each photocopied page along with a record of its relevance to the litigation." . In that case, the total figure for photocopy expenses was "reduced by 50 percent to account for non-necessary copies." . The plaintiffs in this case seek the same reduction, although they argue that the copying costs must be reduced by 50 percent to account for duplicative copies and then again by 50 percent to account for non-necessary copies. I agree with Affymetrix here; only one reduction of 50 percent is necessary.

Therefore, 50 percent of the copying costs sought by Affymetrix will be awarded. However, there were errors

Entry 1: 28 pages at 10 cents per page is $2.80, not $5.60.

Entry 2: 316 pages at 10 cents per page is $31.60, not $63.20.

Entry 186: 20 pages at 10 cents per page is $2.00, not $0.20.

Entry 258: 30 pages at 10 cents per page is $3.00, not $0.30.

Entry 278: 2737 pages at 10 cents per page is $273.70, not $237.70.

Entry 319: 620 pages at 10 cents per page is $62.00, not $6.20.

of calculation in several of the entries in Exhibit C. The true amount sought is $16,626.39, and only 50 percent of that, or $8,313.20, will be awarded.

D. Visual Aids for Markman Hearing

Affymetrix seeks to recover $106,168.75 in costs for the preparation of visual aids for the Markman hearing. These costs are not taxable under Section 1920(4) as exemplifications. See Taxation of Costs at 4 ("Exemplification is the making of an official and certified copy of a document or transcript that is used as evidence. Examples of items that may be exemplified include docket sheets, complaints, medical reports, police reports, weather reports, land records, and criminal records."). Here, Affymetrix seeks taxation of the fees paid to various professionals for their services, which is not within the scope of Section 1920(4), even under a broad reading. See . These costs will not be awarded.

III. Conclusion

For the reasons stated above, costs will be awarded as follows:

$14,981.85 in fees for printed or electronically recorded transcripts necessarily obtained for use in the case; and

$15,688.73 in fees for exemplification and the costs of making copies of any materials where the copies are necessarily obtained for use in the case;

For an award of costs totaling $30,670.58.

It is SO ORDERED.

/s/ George A. O'Toole, Jr.

United States District Judge
